qa_pairs.question: How do secured lines of credit differ from unsecured lines of credit in terms of collateral requirements, interest rates, and credit limits, and what examples of secured lines are mentioned in the context?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Secured lines of credit require collateral, such as home equity for home equity lines of credit (HELOC) or securities for Securities Backed Lines of Credit (SBLOC), whereas unsecured lines of credit do not require collateral.<cite>[S13][S22]</cite></statement> <statement>Secured lines of credit typically have lower interest rates due to reduced risk for lenders, while unsecured lines of credit carry higher interest rates to compensate for the lack of collateral.<cite>[S15][S16]</cite></statement> <statement>Secured lines of credit generally offer higher credit limits compared to unsecured lines, which often have lower limits due to the increased risk for lenders.<cite>[S15][S19]</cite></statement> <statement>Examples of secured lines of credit mentioned in the context include home equity lines of credit (HELOC) and Securities Backed Lines of Credit (SBLOC), also referred to as Pledged Asset Lines.<cite>[S13][S20]</cite></statement>

[S14] Secured lines of credit offer the lender the right to seize the asset in case of non-payment. [S15] Because their risk is lower, secured lines of credit typically come with a higher maximum credit limit and significantly lower interest rate. [S17] A borrower must have a high credit score and good repayment history to meet the eligibility criteria for getting an unsecured line of credit. [S19] Hence, the lenders can minimize their risk by charging high-interest rates and restricting the credit line limit. [S20] Besides the HELOC, another relatively common form of secured LOC is the Securities Backed Line of Credit (SBLOC). [S21] This is also commonly referred to as a Pledged Asset Line. [S22] In this version, the borrower pledges securities (typically stocks, bonds, etc.) to the lender as collateral. [S23] The lender will typically lend less than the full value of the securities pledged, applying various "haircuts," depending on the lenders' assessment of how risky the pledged security is. [S24] For example, a lender might lend up to 80% of the value of a bond, but only 50% of the value of a stock. [S25] It's important to note that these LOCs are designated as non-purpose, meaning the proceeds cannot be used to purchase additional securities, unlike a margin loan. A **line of credit** is a credit facility extended by a bank or other financial institution to a government, business or individual customer that enables the customer to draw on the facility when the customer needs funds. [S2] A financial institution makes available an amount of credit to a business or consumer during a specified period of time.
